title: FeverPAIN Score for Strep Pharyngitis
description: Predicts likelihood of streptococcal pharyngitis and guides antibiotic prescribing decisions.

ranges.interpretation: 13-18% likelihood of streptococcus isolation. No antibiotics recommended. Consider supportive care and symptom management.
30-35% likelihood of streptococcus isolation. Delayed antibiotic prescription may be appropriate. Consider 3-day delayed prescribing strategy.
39-48% likelihood of streptococcus isolation. Delayed antibiotic prescription may be appropriate. Consider 3-day delayed prescribing strategy.
62-65% likelihood of streptococcus isolation. Consider antibiotics if symptoms are severe or patient is systemically unwell. Short delayed prescribing strategy (48 hours) may be appropriate.

references: Little P, Hobbs FD, Moore M, Mant D, Williamson I, McNulty C, et al. Incidence and clinical variables associated with streptococcal throat infections: a prospective diagnostic cohort study. Br J Gen Pract. 2012 Nov;62(604):e787-94.

Little P, Moore M, Hobbs FD, Mant D, McNulty C, Williamson I, et al. Clinical score and rapid antigen detection test to guide antibiotic use for sore throats: randomised controlled trial of PRISM (primary care streptococcal management). BMJ. 2013 Oct 10;347:f5806.
formula: FeverPAIN Score = Sum of positive criteria (1 point each)
notes: For use in patients 3 years and older
FeverPAIN stands for: Fever, Purulence, Attend rapidly, Inflamed tonsils, No cough/coryza
Reduced antibiotic prescribing by 30% in implementation studies
Better utility than Centor score at lower score levels
Consider delayed antibiotic prescribing strategies when appropriate
